cellularAutomata.lib
Class Simulation<T extends Point>

java.lang.Object
  cellularAutomata.lib.Simulation<T>
Type Parameters:
T - A point that specifies a concrete dimension that this simulation will support. Should be a strict subclass of Point.
Direct Known Subclasses:
Simulation1D, Simulation2D
public abstract class Simulation<T extends Point>
extends java.lang.Object

Defines a simulation for a cellular automaton. This class handles the GUI elements for simulations of arbitrary dimension. Implementations are given for 1 and 2 dimensional simulations, but one can easily create a simulation for a higher dimension.

This class offers a factory method that can create a simulation for Rule<Point1D> and Rule<Point2D>, as well as a way to create simulations for other types of Points.

Author:
Kunal Desai, James Grugett, Prasanth Somasundar

Method Detail

getSimulation

public static <T extends Point> Simulation<T> getSimulation(Rule<T> r,
                                                            Visualization v)
This is a factory method takes a rule and a visualization and produces a Simulation suitable for viewing the automaton.

Parameters:
r - A Rule, which must be of Point1D or Point2D, otherwise this method will fail
v - a visualization to use for coloring the states
Returns:
a Simulation that can be used to visualize a cellular automaton.

run

public void run()
Called by the client to start the GUI. If the rules haven't been set, this method will fail. The factory method will automatically set the rules, so the only time this will fail is if you create your own subclass of Simulation

setViewport

public void setViewport(Viewport<T> v)
Allows you to swap Viewports of the program out.

Parameters:
v - a Viewport you want to use to visualize the data.

setVisualization

public void setVisualization(Visualization v)
Allows you to swap out a Visualization (color picker)

Parameters:
v - the new visualization

getState

public abstract State<T> getState()
Gets the current state of the simulation

Returns:
the current state of the simulation

setRule

public abstract void setRule(Rule<T> r)
This method allows for on-the-fly switching with rules, as well as setting the initial rule.

Parameters:
r - the new Rule to use for the simulation.
